questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling for 3 days.  The patient has been unable to perform her activities of daily living because of the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension and diabetes. Temperature is 38°C (102.4°F), blood pressure is 96/71 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right wrist when compared to the left wrist. Passive range of motion of the right wrist results in significant reproducible pain. Range of motion is limited. An arthrocentesis is performed with synovial fluid analysis pending. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals on synovial fluid analysis
History of remote well-healed radial fracture without complications
Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals on synovial fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of immunosuppression from diabetes presents for evaluation of unilateral wrist swelling and pain. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis, significant swelling, pain with range of motion, and limited range of motion of the right wrist, septic arthritis is likely. Arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis would be necessary to make the diagnosis. An overlying soft tissue infection, such as cellulitis where contiguous spread can lead to septic arthritis is a risk factor for the development of septic arthritis.
 

Patients with septic arthritis typically present with monoarticular joint pain and swelling with associated infectious symptoms including fever or malaise. Risk factors for septic arthritis include a history of recent joint surgery, presence of a prosthetic joint, immunosuppression (including diabetes), intravenous drug use, smoking, and an overlying skin infection, ulceration, or wound.  On physical examination, patients will typically appear ill and have a joint effusion, with erythema and warmth of the overlying skin. Patients typically also have significant pain with range of motion, limited range of motion of the affected joint, and inability to bear weight or use of the affected joint.  

Option Analysis

✅ Overlying skin infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals on synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Needle-shaped, negatively-birefringent crystals are found in the synovial fluid of patients with gouty arthritis. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis and immunosuppression from diabetes, a diagnosis of septic arthritis is more likely.  
❌ History of remote well-healed radial fracture without complications:
Incorrect: A fracture that is associated with complications may lead to osteoarthritis that could increase a patient’s risk for septic arthritis, but a well-healed remote fracture without complications would not place this patient at increased risk. Having a joint with pre-existing arthritis from conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, gout, pseudogout, or Charcot arthropathy does increase the risk of septic arthritis.  
❌ Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals on synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals seen on synovial fluid analysis indicates the presence of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals which are seen in  calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals deposition (CPPD) disease.  
❌ Synovial fluid cell count <2000 cells/microL:
Incorrect: A cell count of <2000 cells/microL on synovial fluid analysis is considered non-inflammatory and would not be consistent with septic arthritis. Given that this patient has evidence of sepsis and immunosuppression, a diagnosis of septic arthritis is more likely.

questions.text:
A 73-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right knee pain and swelling for the past 2 days.  The patient has been unable to ambulate secondary to the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension, gout, diabetes, osteoarthritis, and obesity. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 125/71 mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right knee. The patient is unable to bear weight without significant pain. An arthrocentesis is performed. The synovial fluid analysis results from later that day are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Color
Opaque
Culture/Gram stain  
Moderate polymorphonuclear cells on Gram stain
No growth on culture thus far  
Cell Count  
77,532 cells/microL, 95% polymononuclear leukocytes  
Crystal Analysis  
Negative
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of unilateral knee swelling and pain. Given this patient's fever, joint effusion, limited range of motion, significant pain with range of motion, and inability to bear weight on the affected joint, septic arthritis is likely. Arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis shows opaque fluid with a white blood cell count of 77,532 cells/microL, with 95% polymononuclear leukocytes which is consistent with septic arthritis.
 

The diagnosis of septic arthritis is both clinical as well as dependent on results from synovial fluid analysis. Synovial fluid analysis can be used to differentiate between non-inflammatory causes of arthritis like osteoarthritis and inflammatory causes such as rheumatoid arthritis and septic arthritis. What separates septic arthritis is that there are typically >50,000 cells/microL with >90% of those cells being polymorphonuclear cells, and gram stain and culture will be positive.  

Option Analysis

✅ Septic arthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteoarthritis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis from osteoarthritic joints typically have cell counts <2000 cells/microL. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Rheumatoid arthritis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally the range is 5000-50,000 cells/microL. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in patients with gout is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally the range is 5000-50,000 cells/microL. Patients with gouty arthritis will also have evidence of negatively birefringent crystals. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis in patients with calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (pseudogout) is typically inflammatory, with a white blood cell count >2000 cells/microL, but generally in the range of 5000-50,000 cells/microL. Patients will also have evidence of calcium pyrophosphate crystals. This patient's synovial fluid analysis and clinical presentation are more consistent with septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents for follow-up for right knee pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion that has been present for one year. He has been using over-the-counter topical analgesics to manage his pain. He has been referred to physical therapy previously with inconsistent follow-up. He is now noticing that he is not able to walk as far due to the pain. Medical history is significant for hypertension and peptic ulcer disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 138/75 mmHg. BMI is 29 kg/m2. Right knee examination is notable for mild swelling of the knee, tenderness to palpation along the medial joint line, limited range of motion, and crepitus. There is no erythema or warmth. Radiograph of the right knee is shown below. What is the best next step in management?
 

Image reproduced from MDPI open access
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a one-year history of knee pain that persists despite the use of over-the-counter topical analgesics for management of his pain and intermittent physical therapy. Non-pharmacologic management of osteoarthritis is effective and should be recommended to all patients as initial treatment. This includes exercise, weight loss, Tai Chi, and assistive devices. Weight loss is recommended for patients with BMI > 25 kg/m2 because it relieves stress on weight-bearing joints, leading to a reduction in pain and increased mobility. Exercise increases muscle strength and improves range of motion. Tai Chi is a traditional Chinese mind-body practice that improves strength and balance. Patients with knee or hip osteoarthritis with difficulty ambulating may benefit from the use of assistive devices such as braces, canes, or walkers.

If patients do not respond to non-pharmacologic treatment or if they want to add pharmacologic treatment to non-pharmacologic therapy, NSAIDs (either topical or oral) can be added if the patient does not have contraindications. Topical NSAIDs can be prescribed initially for pain management and do not carry the same risks as an oral NSAID. Oral NSAIDs are the recommended initial oral medication; however, there is an increased risk for adverse effects in patients with chronic kidney disease, cardiovascular disease, or risk factors for gastrointestinal bleeding. In patients with intolerance or contraindication to NSAIDs, duloxetine may be used as an alternate oral therapy.

If patients do not respond to first-line pharmacologic management with NSAIDs or duloxetine, second-line treatment with intra-articular injections (glucocorticosteroids or hyaluronic acid) can be offered. Intra-articular glucocorticosteroids reduce inflammation within the joint leading to a reduction in pain and improvement in joint function; however, they are associated with adverse risks to the joint. Intra-articular hyaluronic acid acts as a cushion to lubricate the joint.

Patients with knee osteoarthritis who do not respond to nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic treatments may be referred for surgical consultation for joint replacement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Weight loss counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Total Knee Replacement:
Incorrect: Joint replacement is an option for management of severe arthritis, or for pain and limitation from arthritis that is not responsive to non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy; therefore, he should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral medications first.  
❌ Intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used for patients who have not had relief with non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments, or if they have contraindications to these treatments. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy; therefore, he should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral medications first.  
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Oral steroids are typically not used to treat osteoarthritis which is a non-inflammatory arthritis. This patient has only tried over-the-counter topical analgesics and intermittent physical therapy and should try weight loss, exercise, and prescription topical and oral pain medications.  
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease and should avoid the use of NSAIDs which can increase his risk for gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to severe pain, swelling, and redness in his right big toe. He reports that the pain started abruptly in the middle of the night, waking him from sleep. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history, alcohol consumption of a few beers occasionally on weekends, and a diet rich in carbohydrates. Family history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis in his mother. He denies recent trauma to the foot or history of joint disease. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 145/84 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears to be in pain. Physical examination is significant for tenderness, swelling, and erythema of the metatarsophalangeal joint of the right big toe. There is limitation to both passive and active range of motion. Which of the following factors in this patient's history likely increased his risk of developing this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, warmth, and erythema in his right big toe consistent with “podagra” which is gout of the big toe. In the absence of signs and symptoms suggestive of a joint infection, these findings are consistent with a diagnosis of acute gout. The most likely predisposing factor, in this case, is an increase in uric acid levels caused by the use of hydrochlorothiazide.

Acute gout is inflammatory arthritis that typically presents as sudden onset severe joint pain, often occurring at night or in the early morning with a maximal intensity within 12-24 hours. It is often monoarticular with the first metatarsophalangeal joint (the "big toe") most commonly affected. Other joints such as the knees, ankles, and elbows can be involved. Physical examination will show an erythematous, swollen, and extremely tender joint, even to light touch (hyperesthesia). Light touch or the weight of a bedsheet can cause intense pain. A pathognomonic finding for gout is the presence of painless subcutaneous nodules or tophi most commonly on the olecranon bursa, and joints and pads of the digits of the hands and feet.
 

Gout is caused by hyperuricemia. Causes of hyperuricemia include conditions that lead to decreased clearance of uric acid (hydrochlorothiazide diuretics) as well as conditions that lead to the overproduction of uric acid as detailed in the table below. A diet high in purines as seen with heavy alcohol consumption and a diet rich in red meat or seafood also increases the risk of developing gouty arthritis. Additional predisposing factors include male sex, obesity, diabetes, and dyslipidemia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hydrochlorothiazide use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diet rich in carbohydrates:
Incorrect: Diets high in purine-rich foods, such as red meat and seafood, can increase the risk of developing gout by elevating serum uric acid levels. A diet rich in carbohydrates is not a direct risk factor for developing gout.  
❌ Family history of rheumatoid arthritis (RA):
Incorrect: A family history of RA is a risk factor for the development of RA, which presents with chronic symmetrical joint swelling and pain and morning stiffness typically involving the hands and feet. This patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with acute gout.  
❌ Alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Heavy alcohol consumption can increase the risk of gout by increasing uric acid production, however, his patient reports only occasional alcohol consumption.  
❌ Smoking history:
Incorrect: Smoking is not considered a direct risk factor for gout.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness of the right wrist that started 12 hours ago. She has not had fevers, chills, rashes, or tick bites. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She denies recent trauma to the wrist. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), blood pressure is 133/84 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness, swelling, and erythema of the right wrist with limited passive and active range of motion. There are firm, non-tender nodular lesions present over the elbows bilaterally. Laboratory results are shown below. Diagnostic arthrocentesis is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in synovial fluid analysis?

Laboratory values
Results
Hemoglobin
15.4 g/dL  
Hematocrit
40%  
Leukocyte count  
11,500 /mm3   
Platelet count  
390,000/mm3   
CRP
35 mg/L  
Uric acid  
7.0 mg/dL

choices.text: Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light
Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset severe monoarticular pain, swelling, and redness in the right wrist, and non-tender nodular lesions over the elbows consistent with tophi formation. These findings are highly suggestive of gouty arthritis. In the setting of a suspected acutegouty attack, the gold standard for diagnosis is synovial fluid analysis, which will reveal negatively birefringent, needle-shaped monosodium urate (MSU) crystals. These appear yellow when lying parallel to the polarizing axis and blue when lying perpendicular to the polarizing axis as seen in the image below.  


Picture taken from Osmosis.org
Serum laboratory evaluations for patients with acute gout are often supportive, but not diagnostic. They may reveal leukocytosis, elevated CRP and ESR, and elevated serum uric acid levels, typically greater than 6.8 mg/dL. However, serum uric levels may be normal or below normal due to precipitation from serum into the joint space.

If a patient presents with sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness in the big toe, with no systemic signs of infection, the diagnosis of acute gout can be made clinically. However, if patients lack obvious risk factors for gout, or have never been diagnosed before, then septic arthritis should be ruled out with joint aspiration and analysis of the synovial fluid. If the synovial fluid shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals and yellow, cloudy fluid containing white blood cells (WBCs), the diagnosis of acute gout can be confirmed. However, if it lacks these findings, alternative diagnoses such as pseudogout, septic arthritis, and Lyme arthropathy should be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals, which are associated with pseudogout. Although pseudogout can cause sudden onset joint pain and inflammation, the presence of nodular lesions over the elbows is more suggestive of gouty arthritis.  
❌ Gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: This finding would be suggestive of septic arthritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Although septic arthritis can present with sudden-onset severe monoarticular arthritis, this patient's lack of systemic signs of infection, and the presence of tophi over the elbows make the diagnosis of acute gouty arthritis more likely.  
❌ Positive cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: These antibodies are associated with rheumatoid arthritis which typically presents with chronic symmetric polyarticular joint pain and swelling that is more insidious in onset. This patient’s clinical presentation and findings are more suggestive of acute gouty arthritis.  
❌ Positive PCR for B. burgdorferi:
Incorrect: This finding is indicative of Lyme arthritis, which may present with migratory polyarthritis. This patient has not been exposed to tick bites and does not have a history of a “Bull’s-eye” rash, making this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a 5-year history of bilateral hand pain and stiffness. She has not previously received medical attention for the joint pain and it has progressed over time to affect her feet as well. The stiffness is worse in the morning and when she is inactive for long periods, lasting over an hour and gradually improving with activity. She has no fevers or unintentional weight loss. Medical history is significant for high cholesterol. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 88/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Physical examination shows tenderness and swelling of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints on both hands, as well as metatarsophalangeal joints on both feet. There is no warmth or erythema. She is unable to fully close her fists due to pain and she has reduced grip strength. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would support the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 5-year history of joint pain and swelling involving the bilateral hands and more recently, the feet, which is associated with prolonged morning stiffness, >30 minutes, and improves with activity. This is consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Contractures can also be seen in long-standing RA. These include Swan-neck and Boutonniere deformities.
 

Swan-neck deformities of the digits of the hand of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons 
 

Rheumatoid arthritis causes chronic symmetric polyarticular inflammatory arthritis, most often involving the joints of the hands, wrists, and feet. Patients typically present with over 6 weeks of joint stiffness that is worse in the morning or after prolonged periods of inactivity, lasting 30 minutes or longer; with associated joint swelling and pain. Patients may also report nonspecific systemic symptoms such as fatigue, malaise, depressed mood, and poor appetite.  Rheumatoid arthritis involves the small, peripheral joints with the most commonly affected joints being the proximal interphalangeal or PIP joints and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints of the hands. The small joints of the feet can also be involved as can larger joints. Physical examination is notable for symmetrical swelling with a soft “boggy” feeling indicating synovitis, in addition to tenderness to palpation and pain with range of motion. Warmth and erythema are not typically seen.

The underlying joint inflammation in RA causes the surrounding structures to shorten and stiffen, this can eventually result in contractures. Common contractures seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis include ulnar deviation of the MCP joints; Boutonniere deformities, where there is persistent flexion of the PIP joints and hyperextension of the DIP joints; and Swan-neck deformities, where there is persistent hyperextension of the PIP joints and flexion of the DIP joints.  

Option Analysis

✅ Swan-Neck deformities:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bouchard nodes:
Incorrect: Bouchard nodes are bony enlargements of the proximal interphalangeal joints that can be seen in patients with osteoarthritis. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Xanthomas:
Incorrect: A xanthoma is a cutaneous lipid deposit that is seen in some patients with a history of elevated cholesterol. While this patient has elevated cholesterol, the most likely underlying diagnosis is rheumatoid arthritis and the presence of a xanthoma would not be useful in confirming that diagnosis.  
❌ Malar rash:
Incorrect: A malar rash, also known as a butterfly rash, is an erythematous rash that appears over the bridge of the nose and cheeks, sparing the nasolabial folds. It can be seen in systemic lupus erythematosus which can be associated with joint swelling, but it is not a finding associated with rheumatoid arthritis which is more likely in this patient.  
❌ Tophi:
Incorrect: Tophi are deposits of monosodium urate that can be found in soft tissues, synovial tissues, or bones near the joints in patients with a history of gout. Rheumatoid arthritis is more likely in this patient with chronic symmetrical joint pain, swelling, and stiffness of the hands and feet.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute-onset, severe right foot pain. The patient woke up this morning with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected extremity. The patient denies a history of recent trauma. The patient has experienced three similar episodes in the past year, which were treated adequately with colchicine. Past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals redness, warmth, and a small effusion around the right great toe. A sample of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. Once stabilized, which of the following medications would be most helpful in preventing future recurrences of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute-onset toe pain, erythema, and swelling. Microscopy reveals the presence of needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid. These findings are consistent with an acute gout flare. The patient should initially be treated with indomethacin to manage the acute symptoms. Afterwards, pharmacologic urate-lowering therapy with allopurinol or febuxostat should be administered to prevent future episodes of acute gouty attack.  

Allopurinol is a purine analog that works via competitive inhibition of xanthine oxidase (XO). Allopurinol is first converted by XO into its active metabolite oxypurinol, which is a non-competitive inhibitor of XO. Inhibition of XO decreases serum uric acid levels and increases levels of the upstream molecules hypoxanthine and xanthine; which are more soluble compounds and therefore easier to excrete. As a result, there is a smaller chance of crystals depositing in the joints and tissues.    

Allopurinol is also effective in preventing tumor lysis syndrome in individuals with lymphoma or leukemia, who are receiving anti-cancer therapy. Common side effects of allopurinol include gastrointestinal irritation and rash. In rare cases, the medication can cause Steven-Johnsons syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis.  



Febuxostat, on the other hand, is a non-purine inhibitor of XO. It is reserved for individuals who cannot tolerate allopurinol. Side effects include gastrointestinal disturbance, headache, and hepatotoxicity.  



Option Analysis

✅ Allopurinol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be avoided in patients with a history of gout since it competes with uric acid for excretion via the kidneys. As a result, aspirin can increase the risk of future gout attacks.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are associated with elevated serum uric acid levels. They increase urate reabsorption in the proximal renal tubules and may precipitate a gout attack.  
❌ Fenofibrate:
Incorrect: Fenofibrate is a lipid lowering drug. It is typically effective in the management of hypertriglyceridemia and can reduce the risk of developing acute pancreatitis.  
❌ Prophylactic antibiotics:
Incorrect: Gouty arthritis is caused by either reduced uric acid excretion or excess uric acid production. It is not caused by bacterial infection. Therefore, urate-lowering agents, instead of prophylactic antibiotics, are indicated to prevent recurrent episodes of gout.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe right ankle pain. The pain developed overnight and woke him up from his sleep. He has not traveled recently and has no history of recent trauma. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, and atorvastatin. Family history is significant for osteoarthritis in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows a moderate-sized effusion of the right ankle with surrounding erythema and warmth. Serum creatinine is 0.9 mg/dL. Microscopic examination of the synovial fluid aspirate is shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug indicated to treat this patient’s condition?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Blockade of transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan
Conversion of uric acid to allantoin
Inhibition of renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid

questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute-onset right ankle pain, erythema, and swelling. Light microscopy reveals needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals. These findings are consistent with an acute gout attack.    

First-line treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as indomethacin. NSAIDs work via reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase. In contrast, aspirin and other salicylates should be avoided in gout because they are weak acids and therefore they can compete with uric acid for secretion in the proximal convoluted tubules.    

Glucocorticoids such as methylprednisolone and prednisone can also be used to treat acute gout by inhibiting phospholipase A2.  



Finally, colchicine can treat acute gout by binding tubulin and inhibiting microtubule polymerization, thereby inhibiting neutrophil migration into joints and reducing inflammation. It can also be used for gout prophylaxis and treatment of familial Mediterranean fever. Colchicine is contraindicated in individuals with kidney, liver, or gastrointestinal problems. Moreover, the medication should be used only when NSAIDs and corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective. This precaution exists because colchicine has numerous side effects including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, peripheral neuropathy, rhabdomyolysis, kidney damage, and bone marrow suppression.  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Penicillins act by blocking the transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan. It is indicated in the management of septic arthritis but plays no role in gouty arthritis.  
❌ Xanthine oxidase inhibition:
Incorrect: Allopurinol and febuxostat decrease uric acid levels by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. These medications can prevent recurrent gout attacks and prevent tumor lysis syndrome in patients receiving anti-cancer therapy. They are not effective in treating acute gout attacks.  
❌ Conversion of uric acid to allantoin:
Incorrect: Uricase medications (e.g., rasburicase, pegloticase) catalyze the conversion of uric acid to allantoin, a more soluble and easily excreted product. These agents are not used for acute gout treatment but are typically reserved for severe gout cases that have failed other urate-lowering therapies or to prevent uric acid nephropathy in situations of increased uric acid production, such as tumor lysis syndrome.
✅ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid:
Incorrect: Uricosuric agents (e.g., probenecid, sulfinpyrazone) inhibit renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid, thereby increasing its excretion. These agents are typically reserved for patients who under-excrete uric acid relative to their plasma levels. Uricosuric agents are not effective in the management of acute gout attacks.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for left elbow pain and swelling. The patient is an air conditioning technician, which requires him to move through tight spaces while resting on his knees and elbows. He did not sustain any recent trauma. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Upper arm exam is noncontributory. The patient has swelling at the posterior aspect of the left elbow as shown below. He has full range of motion of the elbow. He reports improvement in pain with full elbow extension and worsening with flexion. The swollen area is mildly tender to touch but is not warm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with posterior elbow swelling and tenderness consistent with olecranon bursitis. The olecranon bursa is a superficial bursa that overlies the triceps tendon and olecranon. Normally, the olecranon bursa is flat, but it can swell when it is irritated or inflamed due to direct trauma, prolonged pressure, or friction (leaning on the elbow or as part of an occupation such as laying carpet). As the bursa does not directly involve the joint, flexion/extension does not typically cause pain. Although if significantly swelling or inflammation is present, patients may experience increased pain with stretching of the bursa with flexion at the elbow.  

In addition to direct trauma, friction, and pressure, olecranon bursitis can be caused by septic bursitis or by underlying inflammatory conditions of the joint space (e.g. gout or osteoarthritis). If these are a concern, a bursal aspiration and analysis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

❌ Triceps tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Triceps tendinopathy results from repetitive elbow extension against resistance. Patients typically report pain at the posterior elbow with resisted elbow extension and tenderness at the triceps insertion at the olecranon. Swelling at the elbow would not be consistent with triceps tendinopathy.   
❌ Distal biceps tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Distal biceps tendon rupture presents following forceful lifting with sudden pain deep in the antecubital fossa. Physical examination often reveals tenderness over the radial tubercle and pain aggravated with resisted flexion and supination of the forearm. There can be swelling at the anterior elbow and a bulge can be seen or palpated at the upper arm which is the recoiled biceps muscle. However, posterior elbow swelling is not seen and is suggestive of olecranon bursitis.  
❌ Medial epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Medial epicondylitis (i.e. golfer’s elbow) is caused by overuse of the wrist, hand flexors, and forearm pronators. Patients typically present with pain over the medial epicondyle with resisted finger and wrist flexion. Posterior elbow swelling would not be expected.  
❌ Lateral epicondylitis:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondylitis (i.e. tennis elbow) is characterized by overuse of wrist extensors. It presents tenderness over the lateral epicondyle and pain with resisted wrist extension, digit extension, and forearm supination. It does not present with posterior elbow swelling.  
✅ Olecranon bursitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate fatigue for one week. She started a new medication for hand pain and stiffness four months ago. Additional medications include ibuprofen, prednisone, and hydroxychloroquine. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.2 °F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 102/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a subcutaneous nodule over her left elbow and evidence of joint dysfunction of the fingers with Boutonniere deformities. Laboratory evaluation shows a  hemoglobin concentration of 10.1 g/dL, leukocyte count of 3,400/mm<sup>3</sup>, and platelet count of 101,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Methylmalonic acid levels are normal. Which of the following agents could have prevented this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has typical clinical findings of rheumatoid arthritis (pain and stiffness of the hands, subcutaneous nodules, joint destruction with boutonniere deformity). Her fatigue and signs of myelosuppression indicate that she was likely started on treatment with methotrexate (MTX).

MTX is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which reduces dihydrofolate to its active intracellular metabolite, tetrahydrofolate. MTX induces a state of functional folate depletion, which is thought to result in gastrointestinal, hematologic, and mucosal side effects. These side effects can be reduced by administering salvage therapy in folinic acid (leucovorin). Leucovorin should be administered as prophylactic therapy within 24–48 hours of starting high-dose treatment with MTX.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mesna:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic cystitis associated with nitrogen-mustard-based chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide) can be prevented by aggressive hydration and coadministration of mesna. It has no role in the prevention of methotrexate-induced myelosuppression.  
❌ Dexrazoxane:
Incorrect: Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent that can help prevent doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.  
✅ Leucovorin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amifostine:
Incorrect: Amifostine is a cytoprotective free-radical scavenger used to reduce nephrotoxicity associated with platinum-containing and alkylating agents and to decrease xerostomia.  
❌ Ondasetron:
Incorrect: Ondansetron is used to treat chemotherapy-associated nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a three-month history of joint pain. He has been experiencing pain, stiffness, and swelling in his fingers and toes. The pain has gradually become worse and makes it difficult for him to work. He has not had pain in the elbows, knees, or lower back. He has no significant past medical history, but his father has psoriasis.  Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg.  Thick, scaly, silvery-white skin plaques with punctate bleeding spots are noted on the extensor surface of both elbows.  Examination of the joints reveals swelling and tenderness of multiple joints of the fingers and toes. Transverse depressions, subungual hyperkeratosis, and pitting of the nails are seen. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be associated with this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is a type of autoimmune arthritis that is associated with the inflammatory skin disorder psoriasis. In PsA inflammation causes joint pain, swelling, and stiffness most commonly in the fingers and toes, but other joints can be affected as well (e.g., elbows, knees, sacroiliac joints). Patients with PsA are typically negative for rheumatoid factor (RF) and antinuclear antibodies (ANA), and have elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). They may also be positive for HLA-B27 (in ~10% of cases).    

Involved joints are typically swollen and tender. Dactylitis is a specific sign of psoriatic arthritis that presents as swelling of the entire digit of the fingers or toes termed “sausage digit”. The inflammation can eventually lead to joint destruction that can be seen on imaging. Because of the association of PsA with psoriasis, the characteristic dry, thick, silvery-white scaly plaques of psoriasis may be seen on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and knees, along with pitting of the nails. Radiographic findings of affected joints may show joint space narrowing and juxta-articular new bone formation.     

CASPAR (Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis) were designed to select patients to enroll in research trials and not for diagnostic purposes. However, since no single finding or test can diagnose psoriatic arthritis, these criteria are helpful when evaluating patients with suspected psoriatic arthritis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Elevated C-reactive protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (Anti-CCP) antibodies:
Incorrect:  Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not commonly seen in patients with psoriatic arthritis. This patient's clinical presentation of scaly white skin plaques and arthritis is consistent with psoriatic arthritis.
❌ Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA):
Incorrect: Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA) are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis. This patient has scaly white skin plaques classic for psoriasis and associated psoriatic arthritis. He does not have renal, pulmonary, or other symptoms that would indicate vasculitis.
❌ Rheumatoid factor (RF):
Incorrect: Although a minority of patients with psoriatic arthritis can have a positive rheumatoid factor (RF), it is more commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and is not a common finding in patients with psoriatic arthritis
❌ Antinuclear antibodies (ANA):
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are seen in autoimmune and connective tissue diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis. A minority of patients with psoriatic arthritis will have a positive ANA, however it is associated more commonly with other connective tissue disease and less often with PsA.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the primary care office with joint pain and nail changes. She has a four-month history of pain, stiffness, and swelling in her fingers, and left knee. She works as a data entry freelancer, and her worsening symptoms have significantly impaired her ability to work. She has a 10-year history of psoriasis which is well controlled with topical agents. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg. Physical examination shows a few patches of silvery-white scales on the extensor surfaces of the elbows. Examination of the nails shows transverse depressions and subungual hyperkeratosis. Multiple joints of the fingers and toes are tender and swollen, as is the left knee. Laboratory studies show a C-reactive protein (CRP) of 8 mg/L and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 23 mm/hr. ANA and anti-ccp antibodies are negative. Which of the following will be most helpful for determining the severity of this patient’s arthritis?

choices.text: Age at initial diagnosis of psoriasis
Presence of an elevated rheumatoid factor

questions.solution:
This patient's joint symptoms, skin findings, and elevated inflammatory markers are consistent with psoriatic arthritis (PsA). Once the diagnosis of PsA is made, assessing disease severity as mild, moderate, or severe is essential to determine the most appropriate treatment. Disease severity can be assessed by evaluating a combination of factors including the number of joints affected, the severity of arthritis, presence of enthesitis (inflammation of tendons and ligaments, often achilles tendon) presence of dactylitis, and the degree of elevation of inflammatory markers. Additionally the impact of the disease on function, and the rapidity of disease progression should be considered when determining the disease severity and the treatment strategy.  

Treatment of mild disease typically involves the use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for joint pain in combination with topical agents (e.g., corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, calcineurin inhibitors) for psoriatic skin lesions.    

Disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are used to treat moderate disease. Methotrexate (MTX) is the first-line treatment in this setting. However, in the event of inadequate response to MTX after 3 months, the second-line agent (leflunomide) can be used.  Folic acid supplementation should be included whenever methotrexate is used. Topical agents can be added to DMARDs to further help control psoriatic plaques.  

Biologics, such as tumor necrosis factor and interleukin inhibitors, are used to treat severe disease. Screening for latent TB should be done prior to starting biologic agents. While biologics may address both the arthritic and skin manifestations of the disease, topical agents for psoriasis should still be offered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Number of joints affected:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Age at diagnosis of PsA:
Incorrect: The patient’s age at the time of the initial diagnosis of PsA is not used to assess PsA disease severity or to guide management.
❌ Presence of Auspitz sign :
Incorrect: A positive Auspitz sign refers to punctate bleeding spots when psoriatic lesions are scraped off and can be helpful in determining the severity of psoriasis; however, the presence of Auspitz sign is not used to determine disease severity in psoriatic arthritis.
❌ Age at initial diagnosis of psoriasis:
Incorrect: The patient’s age at the time of the initial diagnosis of psoriasis is not used to assess PsA disease severity or to guide management.
❌ Presence of an elevated rheumatoid factor :
Incorrect: Positive rheumatoid factor (RF) can be seen in a minority of patients with PsA, however presence or absence of RF is not used to determine disease severity in psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of severe left knee pain and swelling. He has not had any recent trauma, but recalls multiple similar, though less severe, episodes in his wrists bilaterally that have resolved with NSAIDs. Past medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes lisinopril and metformin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg, heart rate is 78/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The left knee is warm and swollen with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Left knee x-ray shows chondrocalcinosis. Joint aspiration is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in synovial fluid analysis?

choices.text: Turbid synovial fluid with positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals
Turbid synovial fluid with negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals
Frank pus and gram-positive cocci in clusters
Clear synovial fluid with white blood cell count under 2,000 microL
Bright red synovial fluid with red blood cells

questions.solution:
This older patient who presents with sudden-onset severe left knee pain and swelling with a warm swollen joint with limited range of motion and chondrocalcinosis on x-ray likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD), or pseudogout. The key diagnostic feature of CPPD on synovial fluid analysis is the presence of positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.     

CPPD is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints and soft tissue, leading to episodes of acute inflammatory arthritis. While no specific blood tests can confirm CPPD, inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are often elevated during acute attacks. Radiographic evaluation may reveal chondrocalcinosis, a characteristic feature indicating calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition in cartilage. The definitive diagnostic modality is synovial fluid analysis from the affected joint, where positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are identified under polarized light microscopy.  

Patients with pseudogout can be asymptomatic with incidental findings of chondrocalcinosis on x-ray, or they may present clinically with acute or chronic joint pain and swelling. Pseudogout typically presents as acute monoarticular or polyarticular joint pain and swelling. However chronic pseudogout can involve the bilateral wrists and small joints of the hands (called “pseudo-rheumatoid arthritis" (pseudo-RA)). Patients with chronic pseudogout can also present with chronic, degenerative arthritis, resembling osteoarthritis.

Option Analysis

✅ Turbid synovial fluid with positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Turbid synovial fluid with negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals :
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals are seen with gout. This patient’s age, history, and the presence of chondrocalcinosis on x-ray make CPPD more likely.
❌ Frank pus and gram-positive cocci in clusters:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD).  Lack of fever and risk factors for septic arthritis, along with a history of recurrent episodes that have resolved with NSAIDs, makes crystal-induced arthritis more likely, and the presence of chondrocalcinosis makes CPPD most likely.
❌ Clear synovial fluid with white blood cell count under 2,000 microL:
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Non-inflammatory joint diseases, such as osteoarthritis, typically present with clear synovial fluid and a low white blood cell count in the synovial fluid. This patient's acute presentation, history of similar episodes, physical examination and x-ray findings are more consistent with CPPD which is an inflammatory joint process.
❌ Bright red synovial fluid with red blood cells :
Incorrect: This patient likely has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). The above finding suggests hemarthrosis. Given the lack of reported trauma or bleeding, hemarthrosis is unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of severe right knee pain, swelling, and difficulty moving the affected joint. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and diabetic nephropathy. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate is 78/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals right knee warmth and swelling with tenderness to palpation and limited range of motion. Laboratory evaluation is significant for creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL and elevated ESR and CRP. X-ray of the right knee is significant for the presence of chondrocalcinosis. Synovial fluid analysis shows a white blood cell count of 10,000 microL and positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with right knee pain, swelling, warmth, tenderness, and limited range of motion, along with radiographic evidence of chondrocalcinosis and positively birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). CPPD is characterized by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, inducing inflammation. For cases where a single large joint is involved, intra-articular glucocorticoids can be used, especially when there is renal impairment and colchicine and NSAIDs may need dose adjustments or are contraindicated.    

Initial management of acute episodes of CPPD often starts with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Colchicine is also often used. Patients with contraindications to NSAIDs, such as those with renal impairment, require alternative therapy. Colchicine may be used in cases of mild to moderate renal impairment, however, renal dosing should be used. For severe acute attacks involving one or two large joints, intra-articular glucocorticoids can provide targeted and potent anti-inflammatory effects. In cases where multiple joints are involved and NSAIDs and colchicine cannot be used or are ineffective, short courses of systemic glucocorticoids may be appropriate. If these initial measures are insufficient, or in cases of recurrent or chronic CPPD, disease-modifying agents such as hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and interleukin-1 inhibitors can be considered.  

Option Analysis

❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Colchicine can be used to treat CPPD however in this patient with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids would be the preferred treatment.
❌ Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs):
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly used to treat CPPD; however, in patients with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, intra-articular glucocorticoids would be the preferred treatment.
✅ Intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: This patient has calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). Methotrexate can be used to treat calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease; however, it is typically reserved for refractory cases. In patients with renal impairment and monoarticular arthritis, initial treatment with intra-articular glucocorticoids would be preferred.
❌ Physical therapy and weight loss:
Incorrect: Physical therapy and weight loss are important adjuncts for managing chronic joint pain and improving joint function, but they are not the primary treatment for acute symptom relief in calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD). They should be recommended as part of a comprehensive management plan.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with a one-week history of pain and swelling in his knees and ankles. Three weeks prior to the onset of his joint symptoms, he had an episode of nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain that resolved on its own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On physical examination, there is conjunctivitis bilaterally. The right knee is tender, warm, and swollen. Additionally, there is tenderness of the sacroiliac joints and the left Achilles tendon insertion site. Which of the following best characterizes the pattern of joint involvement that is most often seen with this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: Symmetric arthritis of the small joints

questions.solution:
This patient’s joint, Achilles tendon, and eye findings after a recent enteric infection are consistent with reactive arthritis. This disease typically presents with asymmetric oligoarthritis, usually involving the large joints of the lower extremities (e.g. knees, ankles).  

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy that presents as joint inflammation typically after an enteric or genitourinary tract infection (e.g. urethritis). Common causative organisms include Chlamydia trachomatis, Salmonella spp., and Shigella spp. Joint pain typically occurs days to weeks after the infection, and joint examination may reveal tenderness, warmth, and effusions. Inflammation of the sacroiliac joints and at the attachment sites of tendon to bone (enthesitis) is common.  

Other manifestations include dactylitis (“sausage digits”), conjunctivitis, or uveitis; painless oral ulcers; cardiac conduction disturbances; and aortitis. A specific skin finding, keratoderma blennorrhagicum (hyperkeratotic nodules on the palms and soles), may also be seen.   

Option Analysis

✅ Asymmetric oligoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Symmetric polyarthritis:
Incorrect: Symmetric polyarthritis is more typically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient’s history of prior gastrointestinal infection, eye involvement, and Achilles enthesitis is more indicative of reactive arthritis.
❌ Migratory polyarthritis:
Incorrect: Migratory polyarthritis is associated with several diseases, including acute rheumatic fever and gout. This presentation of joint pain, sacroiliac tenderness, Achilles enthesitis, and conjunctivitis following a gastrointestinal infection is more consistent with reactive arthritis. 
❌ Symmetric arthritis of the small joints:
Incorrect: Symmetric involvement of small joints (e.g. hands, feet) would be more indicative of rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s history and presentation is more consistent with reactive arthritis. 
❌ Monoarthritis:
Incorrect: Monoarthritis is seen in septic arthritis and crystal deposition diseases (e.g. gout, pseudogout). This patient’s history and presentation is more consistent with reactive arthritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 3 years ago and was started on a short course of corticosteroids and methotrexate. However, due to severe oral ulcers and diarrhea, the patient asks the physician if she can stop using methotrexate and switch to a medication that inhibits tumor necrosis factor (TNF) that she read about on the internet. The physician agrees on the use of a TNF inhibitor instead of methotrexate. Which of the following should the physician tell the patient about this medication?

choices.text: These medications can increase the risk of lymphomas.
Unlike methotrexate, this new medication does not slow down joint damage.
It is common to prescribe multiple medications from the TNF inhibitor class to achieve the best outcomes.
No testing is required before starting this medication.

questions.solution:
The physician decided to start this patient on a TNF inhibitor after she experienced side effects while taking methotrexate. TNF inhibitors are members of a class of medications called disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) that can be used in rheumatoid arthritis to decrease joint damage. Apart from rheumatoid arthritis, TNF inhibitors can also be used in the treatment of psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disorders, and ankylosing spondylitis. The discovery of TNF inhibitors was a major step in the therapeutic approach to rheumatic disease.

TNF is a major proinflammatory cytokine that is mainly produced by activated macrophages but can also be produced by lymphocytes and natural killer cells. Soluble TNF then binds to its receptors and signals the production of other cytokines (e.g., IL-1, IL-6). TNF plays an important role in many autoimmune disorders and inflammatory disorders, but also is involved in the defense against infections (e.g., tuberculosis) and tumors.

There are 5 TNF inhibitors in use today, four monoclonal antibodies against TNF (e.g., infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, and golimumab), and one soluble TNF receptor (etanercept).

TNF inhibitors are associated with significant side effects, some of which can be lethal. The most common side effects include:

  • Infections: TNF inhibitors increase the risk of many infections, including viral, bacterial, and fungal infections. These infections can sometimes be lethal. In addition, it has been shown that the use of TNF inhibitors can lead to the reactivation of tuberculosis and hepatitis B and C. Therefore, it is recommended that all patients be tested for active/latent TB, HIV, and hepatitis B, and C before starting the treatment with TNF inhibitors.
  • Hepatotoxicity: Which can be severe and lead to fulminant hepatic failure.
  • Malignancies: TNF inhibitors increase the risk of malignancy, especially lymphomas.
  • Congestive heart failure: although TNF inhibitors do not lead to CHF, patients with preexisting CHF taking TNF inhibitors can develop worsening of cardiac function and increased mortality. Therefore, TNF inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with moderate to severe CHF.
  • Demyelinating disorders: This includes optic neuritis, myelitis, transverse myelitis, and guillain-barre syndrome. Patients with preexisting demyelinating disorders should avoid the use of TNF inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

✅ These medications can increase the risk of lymphomas.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Unlike methotrexate, this new medication does not slow down joint damage.:
Incorrect: TNF inhibitors are considered disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) and like methotrexate, they moderate the joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis patients.  
❌ This medication has no contraindications.  :
Incorrect: TNF inhibitors do have a few contraindications, including active infections, moderate to severe heart failure, and hypersensitivity reactions.  
❌ It is common to prescribe multiple medications from the TNF inhibitor class to achieve the best outcomes.  :
Incorrect: While non-biological DMARDs like methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide can be used in conjunction with biological DMARDs to achieve a better outcome, the use of a TNF inhibitor with another biological immunosuppressant is contraindicated.  
❌ No testing is required before starting this medication.  :
Incorrect: The use of TNF inhibitors can lead to the activation of many severe diseases including hepatitis B and C, HIV, and tuberculosis. Therefore, all patients should be tested for active/latent TB, HIV, and hepatitis B and C.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of frequent episodes of color changes and pain in her fingers when she is exposed to cold temperatures. She also has had progressive tightening and thickening of the skin on her hands and forearms for the past 6 months. She mentions frequent heartburn and difficulty swallowing. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the skin appears shiny and tight with decreased mobility over the fingers bilaterally and extending proximally to the elbows. There are no other areas of skin thickening or tightening. Full strength is present in the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would most likely be present given this patient’s likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Erythema of the cheeks sparing the nasolabial folds
Excessive hair growth on the face and body
Erythematous, papulosquamous eruption over the dorsal surfaces of the knuckles
Firm white nodules on the fingers

questions.solution:
This 36-year-old woman with skin thickening on her hands and forearms, Raynaud phenomenon, and gastroesophageal symptoms likely has systemic sclerosis. Her symptoms are consistent with CREST syndrome. Calcinosis cutis is the presence of calcifications in the skin and subcutaneous tissue that can present as firm white nodules, particularly on the hands and feet. It is one of the manifestations of CREST syndrome.  

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic connective tissue disorder characterized by connective tissue thickening due to fibroblast dysfunction and increased collagen and ground substance production. This fibrosis of SSc affects the skin, causing tight and thickened skin, and it can affect internal organs as well. Different disease subsets are associated with different patterns of organ involvement.  

Patients like this one with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis typically present with puffy fingers distal to the metacarpophalangeal joints and develop skin sclerosis distal to the elbows (involving the forearms) and knees, sparing the trunk and proximal extremities. They may also have manifestations of CREST syndrome, which includes Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasias.  

Raynaud phenomenon is a condition that affects blood flow, usually in the fingers and toes. When patients are exposed to cold temperatures or emotional stress, the blood vessels narrow, leading to reduced blood supply to the fingers, causing them to turn white or blue and to feel cold and numb. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include reflux symptoms and voice hoarseness as well esophageal dysmotility and dysphagia.  

Patients with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis typically present with puffy hands and develop skin thickening that extends to the upper arms, thighs, and trunk. Patients with diffuse disease can also have rapid progression of skin thickening with early development of lung fibrosis; they also have an increased risk of renal crisis and cardiac involvement.  



Option Analysis

❌ Erythema of the cheeks sparing the nasolabial folds:
Incorrect: A malar rash is an erythematous rash over the cheeks and bridge of the nose sparing the nasolabial folds. It is frequently seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is not seen with systemic sclerosis, which is the likely diagnosis in this case.
❌ Excessive hair growth on the face and body:
Incorrect: Hirsutism is excessive hair growth on the face and body and is most commonly seen in conditions associated with hormonal imbalances (e.g., polycystic ovarian syndrome, Cushing syndrome). It is not seen with systemic sclerosis, which is the likely diagnosis in this case.
❌ Erythematous, papulosquamous eruption over the dorsal surfaces of the knuckles:
Incorrect: Gottron papules are distinct, flat-topped, violaceous to erythematous papules over the dorsal surfaces of the finger joints. This type of rash is seen in patients with dermatomyositis. This patient’s history and physical examination are more suggestive of systemic sclerosis.
✅ Firm white nodules on the fingers:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Purple discoloration of the eyelids:
Incorrect: Soft, blue-purple discoloration on the eyelids is suggestive of a heliotrope rash. This rash is characteristic of dermatomyositis, an inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. This patient’s history and physical examination are more suggestive of systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic because of joint pain for the last seven months. The pain is in the joints of both hands; it is most severe after waking up and decreases throughout the day. In addition, it is difficult to move her hand or hold any object in the morning, which occurs for the first half an hour after waking. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. On physical examination, both hands have warmth and tenderness in several metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The patient is prescribed medication to decrease the joint damage. This medication works by inhibiting tetrahydrofolate synthesis. Which of the following is the most likely medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has most likely developed rheumatoid arthritis and was prescribed methotrexate to prevent further joint damage. Methotrexate is a non-biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and is used as the first-line treatment of rheumatoid arthritis as it halts the disease progression.

Methotrexate inhibits the proliferation of immune cells and thus inhibits the immune response via multiple mechanisms of action. The main effect of methotrexate is inhibiting the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHTFR). Tetrahydrofolate is the active form of folate needed to make purines and pyrimidine bases and thus make DNA and RNA. By inhibiting DHFTR, methotrexate inhibits the synthesis of DNA and RNA required for cellular division and immune response, inhibiting the proliferation of immune cells. This is also the mechanism by which methotrexate can be used to treat some cancers. It can also inhibit protein synthesis.

Adenosine has anti-inflammatory effects and suppresses T- and B-cell proliferation and response. In addition, methotrexate has another mechanism of action that helps reduce immune response. It inhibits an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, which results in the accumulation of adenosine.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Methotrexate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Leflunomide:
Incorrect:  Leflunomide is an antimetabolite that inhibits the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines. It works by inhibiting the dihydroorotate dehydrogenase enzyme, thereby inhibiting the synthesis of orotic acid from carbamoyl phosphate.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids have anti-inflammatory effects and can be used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis to decrease inflammation and pain. They do not inhibit the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.  
❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen is an NSAID that can be used to treat the pain in rheumatoid arthritis. It works via the inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes and inhibits prostaglandins' synthesis. It has no direct effect on the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.  
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Acetaminophen acts in the central nervous system by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins and thus reduces fever and pain. It does not affect the peripheral inflamed tissues nor inhibit the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a follow-up of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis five years ago. The patient’s only medication is methotrexate which she takes regularly. The patient’s last flare of rheumatoid arthritis was one year ago, and the dose of methotrexate was subsequently increased. The patient does not drink alcohol or use nicotine products. At the end of the visit, the patient is again counseled on the potential adverse effects of methotrexate. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which is now stable on treatment with methotrexate.  Methotrexate is an antimetabolite that inhibits the dihydrofolate reductase enzyme, preventing the synthesis of tetrahydrofolate. Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for RA as it decreases joint damage and improves joint function. It is also used in other connective tissue disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, psoriasis), some cancers (e.g., primarily leukemia/lymphoma), and ectopic pregnancy. It should be started as soon as possible to suppress the progression of joint damage.

Gastrointestinal manifestations are the most common side effects (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain). Methotrexate can also cause oral ulcers. The most severe side effects are liver toxicity (manifesting as asymptomatic liver enzyme elevations or hepatic steatosis) and pulmonary fibrosis. Finally, because it is a folate antagonist and immunosuppressive, methotrexate can lead to megaloblastic anemia and leukopenia.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Elevation of liver enzymes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ QT-segment prolongation:
Incorrect:  QT-segment prolongation is associated with several medications, including class I and III antiarrhythmics, ondansetron, and haloperidol. Methotrexate is not associated with QT-segment prolongation  
❌ Microcytic anemia:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is associated with macrocytic anemia due to folate deficiency, not microcytic anemia. Microcytic anemia could be seen in iron deficiency.  
❌ Gingival hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is seen in patients taking cyclosporine, phenytoin, or rarely calcium channel blockers. It is not a side effect of methotrexate use.  
❌ Photosensitivity:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is not associated with photosensitivity. Some medications that can cause photosensitivity include sulfonamides and tetracyclines.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the clinic due to fatigue and decreased energy for several months. The patient states he has no energy to do most routine activities. A review of systems is positive for mouth pain, nausea, and diarrhea. Medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, for which the patient takes methotrexate. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor and ulcers on the buccal mucosa. Laboratory evaluation shows pancytopenia and normal renal function. The peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic erythrocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis. Although it is generally safe and well-tolerated, toxicity can develop, especially in patients taking higher doses. This patient is most likely having methotrexate toxicity given the pancytopenia, macrocytosis, and mucosal ulcers.

Methotrexate toxicity can lead to myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, or pancytopenia) which can be severe and life-threatening. Other severe toxicities include liver damage (steatosis or fibrosis), pulmonary fibrosis, and, in rare cases, kidney failure.

Treating myelosuppression in methotrexate toxicity is extremely important and should be started immediately. Since the bone marrow suppression by methotrexate is due to folate antagonism, it can be reversed using leucovorin. Leucovorin is a reduced form of folate that does not need activation (i.e. reduction) by dihydrofolate reductase, the enzyme inhibited by methotrexate. Therefore, leucovorin bypasses the inhibitory effects of methotrexate and reverses bone marrow suppression. In addition, leucovorin can also change the gastrointestinal toxicity of methotrexate.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon is used in beta-blocker toxicity; it would not treat methotrexate toxicity.  
✅ Leucovorin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mesna:
Incorrect: Mesna prevents nephrotoxicity and hemorrhagic cystitis in patients taking cyclophosphamide. It is not used for methotrexate toxicity.  
❌ Protamine sulfate:
Incorrect: Protamine sulfate is the antidote to heparin and would not treat methotrexate toxicity.  
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect:  Sodium bicarbonate can help in renal failure associated with methotrexate toxicity. However, this patient’s kidney function is normal.
